# ECE 334 - Quantum Physics II


## Lecture 1 - Postulates of Quantum Mechanics

1) State if a physical system described by a wavefunction $\ket{\psi(t)}$ in a Hilbert space (vector space).

** Example **

> $\ket{\psi} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\ket{\uparrow} + \ket{\downarrow})$

2) Every measurable quantity / observable $A$ is described by an operator $\hat{A}$.

** Example **

> position of $\hat{x}$, momentum $\hat{p}$ angular momentum $\hat{J}$, spin $\hat{S}$, and energy $\hat{H}$

3) Result of a measurement of observable $A$ is an eigenvalue of $\hat{A}$.

4) Probability of measuring eigenvalue $a_{i}$ of $A$ is $|\braket{A_{i}|\psi}|^{2}$ (Born rule) $\hat{A}\ket{A_{i}} = a_{i}\ket{A_{i}}$.

5) After measuring A, the state is left in the eigenstate of $A$ corresponding to the measured eigenvalue (measure $a_{i} \rightarrow$ new state $\ket{A_{i}}$

6) Time evolution is generated by Shrodinger equation

## Lecture 4 - Properties of Operators

### Adjoint Operators

$\bra{X}\hat{A}^{\dag}\ket{Y} = \bra{X}\hat{A}\ket{Y}^{*}$

** Example **

> $(a \hat{A} b \hat{B} \ket{Z})^{\dag} = \bra{Z} \hat{B}^{\dag} b^{*} \hat{A}^{\dag} a^{*}$

### Commutator of Two Operators

$[\hat{A}, \hat{B}] = \hat{A} \hat{B} - \hat{B} \hat{A}$

Two operators $\hat{A}$, $\hat{B}$ commute if $[\hat{A}, \hat{B}] = 0$

Useful identities

- $[\hat{X}, \hat{Y} \hat{Z}] = \hat{Y} [\hat{X}, \hat{Z}] + [\hat{X}, \hat{Y}] \hat{Z}$
- $[\hat{X} \hat{Y}, \hat{Z}] = \hat{X} [\hat{Y}, \hat{Z}] + [\hat{X}, \hat{Z}] \hat{Y}$

### Function of Operators

if $f(x) = \Sigma_{i} a_{i} x^{i}$ then $f(\hat{X}) = \Sigma_i a_{i} \hat{X}^{i}$

if $[\hat{A}, \hat{B}] = 0$ then $[\hat{A}, f(\hat{B})] = 0$

### Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors of Operators

$\hat{A}\ket{A_{i}} = a_{i}\ket{A_{i}}$

### Matrix Representation of Operators

Bras can be written as row vectors and Kets can be written as column vectors. 

If the eigenstates of an operator are a complete set of orthnormal basis states, $\Sigma_{n} \ket{\psi_{n}} \bra{\psi_{n}} = I$. 

Operator can be written in matrix form where $\hat{A} = \Sigma_{n,m} A_{m,n} \ket{\psi_{n}} \bra{\psi_{m}}$ with $A_{m,n} = \bra{\psi_{m}} \hat{A} \ket{\psi_{n}}$

## Lecture 5 - Hermitian Operators

Hermitian operators $\hat{A}= \hat{A}^{\dag}$

** Theorem **

> Eigenvalues of Hermitian operators are real.

** Corollary **

> If eigenvalues of Hermitian operators $\hat{A}$ are non degenerate (no duplicates), then eigenalues of $\hat{A}$ are orthogonal to each other.

** Theorem **

> The eigenstates of a Hermitian operator are a complete set of orthonormal basis states. The operator is diagonal in this eigenbasis with diagonal elements equal to the eigenvalues.

** Theorem **

> If two Hermitian operators $\hat{A}$ and $\hat{B}$ commute, and $\hat{A}$ has no degenerate eigenvalues, then an eigenvector of $\hat{A}$ is also eigenvector of \hat{B}.


## Lecture 6 Measurement

The measurement probability is

$P(a_{i}) = \frac{|\braket{A_{i} | \psi}|^{2}}{\braket{\psi | \psi}}$

In the case of degeneracy (same eigenvalue but different eigenstates), the measurement probability becomes

$P(a_{n}) = \Sigma_{n} \frac{|\braket{A_{n} | \psi}|^{2}}{\braket{\psi | \psi}}$

The expectation value is 

$\braket{\hat{A}} = \frac{\bra{\psi} \hat{A} \ket{\psi}}{\braket{\psi | \psi}}$

## Lecture 7 - Time Evolution (WIP)

Time dependant Shrodinger equation

$i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial{t}} \ket{\psi(t)} = \hat{H} \ket{\psi(t)}$

Time independant Shrodinger equation

let $\hat{H} = \hat{H}(q)$ and $\ket{\psi (t)} = \ket{\psi (q,t)} = \ket{\phi (q)} f(t)$ then

1) $\hat{H}(q) \ket{\phi (q)} = E \ket{\phi (q)}$

2) $i \hbar \frac{\partial{f(t)}}{\partial{t}} = E f(t) \rightarrow f(t) = e^{-\frac{iE}{\hbar}(t-t_{0})}$

** Corrolary **

> Quantum states $\ket{\phi(q)}$ obeying the time-independant Shrodinger equation have a special property $\rightarrow$ "stationary states"

Expectation value does not depend on time $\braket{\hat{A}} = \braket{\hat{A}(t)}$

$\psi (q,t) = \Sigma_{n} a_{n} e^{-\frac{iE}{\hbar}(t-t_{0})} \ket{\psi_{n} (q)}$, where $H(q) \ket{\phi_{n}} = E_{n} \ket{\phi_{n}}$

## Lecture 8 - Annihilation, Creation, and Number Operators

Creation operator (raising)

$a^{\dag} = \frac{1}{\sqrt(2 \hbar m w)} (-i \hat{p} + mw \hat{x})$

Annihilation operator (lowering)

$a = \frac{1}{\sqrt(2 \hbar m w)} (i \hat{p} + mw \hat{x})$

where

$\hat{p} = -i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial{x}} = -i \sqrt{\frac{\hbar mw}{2}} (a - a^{\dag})$

$\hat{x} = x = \sqrt{\frac{\hbar}{2 mw}} (a + a^{\dag})$

Note that $[x_{i}, x_{j}] = [p_{i}, p_{j}] = 0$ and $[x, p] = i \hbar \delta_{i,j}$

### Properties of Creation and Annihilation Operators

$[a, a^{\dag}] = 1$

We define the number operator

$\hat{N}\ket{n} = a^{\dag}a \ket{n} = (aa^{\dag} - 1) \ket{n}$

### Applying the Creation and Annihilation Operators

$a^{\dag} \ket{n} = \sqrt{n+1} \ket{n+1}$

$a \ket{n} = \sqrt{n} \ket{n-1}$

### Kronecker Delta

$\delta_{i,j} = \begin{cases} 0 \quad &\text{if} \quad i \neq j \\ 1 &\text{if} \quad i=j \end{cases}$

$\bra{n'} \hat{N} \ket{n} = n \braket{n'|n} = n \delta_{n,n'}$


### Quantum Harmonic Oscillator

$\hat{H} = \frac{\hat{p}^2}{2m} + \frac{mw \hat{x}^{2}}{2} = \hbar w(a^{\dag}a + \frac{1}{2}) = \hbar w(n + \frac{1}{2})$

** Example **

> $\ket{\psi(0)} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} (\ket{0} + \ket{1})$ then $\ket{\psi(t)} =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} (e^{\frac{-i E_{0} t}{\hbar}} \ket{0} + e^{\frac{-i E_{1} t}{\hbar}}  \ket{1})$

## Lecture 9 - Angular Momentum

Orbital angular momentum is 

$\vec{L} = \vec{R} \times \vec{P}$

where $\vec{R} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ and $\vec{P} = \begin{pmatrix} p_{x} \\ p_{y} \\ p_{z} \end{pmatrix}$

$\hat{L}_{x} = \hat{y} \hat{p}_{z} - \hat{z} \hat{p}_{y}$

$\hat{L}_{y} = \hat{z} \hat{p}_{x} - \hat{x} \hat{p}_{z}$

$\hat{L}_{z} = \hat{x} \hat{p}_{y} - \hat{y} \hat{p}_{x}$

$[\hat{L}_{i}, \hat{L}_{j}] = i \hbar \epsilon_{i,j,k} \hat{L}_{k}$

### Levi Civita Tensor

$\epsilon_{i,j,k} = \begin{cases} 1 \quad &\text{if} \quad (i,j,k) = (1,2,3), (2,3,1), (3,1,2) \\ -1 &\text{if} \quad (i,j,k) = (3,2,1), (2,1,3), (1,3,2) \\ 0 \quad &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}$

## Lecture 10 - Total Angular Momentum

Rebrand all $L$ into $J$

$J^{2} = J_{z}^{2} + J_{y}^{2} + J_{z}^{2}$

$J^{2}$ commute with everything.

$J^{2} \ket{a, b} = a \ket{a, b}$

$J_{z} \ket{a, b} = b \ket{a, b}$

$J_{\pm} = J_{x} \pm i J_{y}$

$a-b \geq 0$

$\hat{J}_{\pm} \ket{a, b} = c \ket{a, b \pm \hbar}$

## Lecture 11 - Total Angular Momentum (Continued)

$J^{2} \ket{j, m} = \hbar^{2} j (j + 1) \ket{j, m}$

$J_{z} \ket{j, m} = m \hbar \ket{j, m}$

$-j \leq m \leq j$ increments of 1

$\hat{J} = \hat{L} + \hat{S}$ where $\hat{L}$ is the orbital angular momentum and $\hat{S}$ is the intrinsic spin.

$\hat{S}^{2} \ket{s, m} = \hbar^{2} s(s + 1) \ket {s, m}$

$\hat{S}_{z} \ket{s, m} = \hbar m \ket{s, m}$

$\hat{S}_{\pm} \ket{s, m \pm 1} = \hbar \sqrt{s(s + 1) - m (m \pm 1)} \ket{s, m \pm 1}$

$S_{x} = \frac{1}{2} (S_{+} + S_{-})$

$S_{y} = \frac{1}{2i} (S_{+} + S_{-})$

## Lecture 13 - 2D Quantum Harmonic Oscillator

$\hat{H}_{x,y} = \frac{\hat{p}_{x}^{2}}{2m} + \frac{\hat{p}_{y}^{2}}{2m} + \frac{m w^{2}}{2} (\hat{x}^{2} + \hat{y}^{2}) = \hbar w (\hat{a}_{x}^{\dag} \hat{a}_{x} + \frac{1}{2}) + \hbar w (\hat{a}_{y}^{\dag} \hat{a}_{y} + \frac{1}{2})$

$E_{x,y} = E_{x,n} + E{y, m} = \hbar w (n_{x} + n_{y} + 1)$

## Lecture 14 - 2D Quantum Harmonic Oscillator (Continued)

$a_{1} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} (a_{x} - i a_{y})$

$a_{2} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} (a_{x} + i a_{y})$

$L_{z} = \hbar (a_{1}^{\dag} a_{1} - a_{2}^{\dag} a_{2})$

$H_{x,y} = \hbar w (a_{1}^{\dag} a_{1} + a_{2}^{\dag} a_{2} + 1)$

$\ket{0, 1} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi} x_{0}^{2}} e^{- \frac{r^{2}}{2 x_{0}}} r e^{- i \phi}$

## Lecture 15 Centroid Potentials

$\vec{L} = \frac{\hbar}{i} \vec{r} \times \vec{\nabla}$

$\vec{\nabla} = \hat{r} \frac{\partial}{\partial{r}} + \hat{\theta} \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial}{\partial{theta}} + \hat{\rho} \frac{1}{r sin(\theta)} \frac{\partial}{\partial{\rho}}$

$L^{2} = - \hbar^{2} (\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial{\theta^{2}}} + cot(\theta) \frac{\partial}{\partial{\theta}} + \frac{1}{sin^{2}(\theta)} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial{\rho^{2}}})$

$L_{x} = -i \hbar (- sin(\rho) \frac{\partial}{\partial{\theta}} - cot(\theta) cos(\rho) \frac{\partial}{\partial{\rho}})$

$L_{y} = -i \hbar (cos(\rho) \frac{\partial}{\partial{\theta}} + cot(\theta) sin(\rho) \frac{\partial}{\partial{\rho}})$

$L_{z} = -i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial{\rho}}$

$\Phi(\rho) = e^{im\rho}$

$\psi(r. \theta, \rho) = R(r) Y_{l}^{m} (\theta, \rho) = R(r) \Theta (\theta) \Phi (\rho)$

$\Theta(\theta) = A \Rho_{l}^{m} (cos \theta)$

$\Rho_{l}^{m} = (1 - x^{2})^{\frac{|m|}{2}} (\frac{d}{dx})^{|m|} \Rho_{l}(x)$

$\Rho_{l}(x) = \frac{1}{2^{l} l!} (\frac{d}{dx})^{l} (x^{2} - 1)^{l}$

## Lecture 16 - Centroid Potentials (Continued)

$\frac{d^{2}u}{d \rho^{2}} = u (1 - \frac{\rho_{0}}{\rho} + \frac{l(l + 1)}{\rho^{2}})$
